Bacterial
DNA Analysis

Identify and characterize the bacteria in the microbiome, which is the community of microorgnisms that live in and on the human body.

Fecal samples are collected and preserved

To later perform bacterial genetic analysis, a fecal sample is collected form a person and preservedin a chemical liquid solution that prevents the DNA in the sample from degrading.

DNA is extracted from the samples

Next, the DNA is extracted from the fecal samples using specialized laboratory techniques.
This DNA contains the genetic material of the microorganisms in the samples.

The 16S rRNA gene is amplified

The 16S rRNA gene is a specific gene found in all bacteria, and it is used as a marker for bacterial identification.
To amplify this gene, a technique called polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is used, which makes many copies of the gene.

The amplified DNA is sequenced

A sequencing machine is used to determine the order of the nucleotides (the building blocks of DNA) in the gene.
This sequence is unique for each bacterial species, so by comparing the sequence of the amplified DNA to a database of known sequences, the bacteria present in the sample can be identified.

The data is analyzed

Specialized software is used to analyze the data and determine the types and abundances of bacteria in the sample.
This can provide insights into the overall makeup of the gut microbiome and help understand how it may be impacting the health of the individual.

Learn More

WHAT IS THE GUT MICROBIOME?

The gut microbiome is the community of microorganisms (mostly bacteria, but also viruses, fungi, and protozoa) that live in the digestive tracts of animals, including humans. The gut microbiome plays an important role in maintaining the health and well-being of its host by performing a variety of functions, such as aiding in the digestion of food, producing vitamins and other important molecules, and supporting the immune system. The gut microbiome is a complex and dynamic ecosystem that is influenced by a variety of factors, including diet, lifestyle, genetics, and the environment.

HOW DOES REBILANCE HANDLE GUT MICROBIOME DATA ETHICALLY?

It is important for us to obtain informed consent from individuals before collecting and analyzing their gut microbiome samples. This means that the individuals are fully informed about the purpose and nature of the service.

The results of gut microbiome analysis may reveal sensitive personal information about an individual’s health and lifestyle, and it is important to protect the privacy and confidentiality of this information. This involves using secure data storage and handling practices, and de-identifying the samples unless strictly required.

HOW IS FECAL SAMPLE COLLECTED FOR 16 R-RNA ANALYSIS?

Obtain a clean container with a tight-fitting lid and stabilizing chemical solution from the provided sampling kit. Follow the instructions in the kit to collect a small amount of feces and place it in the container. Close the lid tightly. Label the container with the date, time, and your name (if applicable). Store the container at a cool temperature (such as in a refrigerator) until it can be sent to the laboratory for analysis by postage. Handle the sample with care and follow proper hygiene practices to avoid contamination. Follow any specific instructions provided by the REBILANCE laboratory or sampling kit provider regarding the collection and handling of the sample.

ARE THERE ANY CONDITIONS OR DISEASES THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH AN IMBALANCE IN THE GUT MICROBIOME?

An imbalance in the gut microbiome, also known as dysbiosis, has been associated with a number of conditions and diseases. Some examples include:

  • Inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD): such as Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis: Dysbiosis has been linked to the development and severity of IBD.
  • Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS): Dysbiosis has been suggested as a possible contributing factor to the development of IBS.
  • Obesity: Some studies have found an association between an imbalance in the gut microbiome and obesity, although the exact relationship is not yet fully understood.
  • Allergies and asthma: Dysbiosis has been linked to an increased risk of allergies and asthma in children.
  • Type 2 diabetes: Some research suggests that an imbalance in the gut microbiome may contribute to the development of type 2 diabetes.
  • Autistic spectrum disorder (ASD): Studies have found differences in the gut microbiome of individuals with ASD compared to those without ASD.
  • Mental health conditions: Some studies have found an association between an imbalance in the gut microbiome and mental health conditions such as depression, anxiety, and stress.

It is important to note that these associations do not necessarily mean that dysbiosis is the cause of these conditions, and more research is needed to fully understand the relationship between the gut microbiome and these conditions.

Match
and Compare

Find a suitable healthy match from our proprietary database of Danish microbiome profiles. This match will serve as the customer's ideal bacterial goal and will be the basis of the personalized probiotic.
